Class rivalry will be temporarily
revived this afternoon at 4 o'clock
When the first starting pistol will
be fired in the Annual Inter-class
Track Meet.
An attractive card of events has
been arranged. Any man with any
talent at all on the track will be
able to find a favorable opening.
The races and other competitions
are as follows: 100, 220 and 440Yard dashes, 880-yard, mile and 2mile runs, high and low hurdles,
running high jump, running broad
Jump, javelin and discus throws,
and shotput and pole vault.
The object of the meet, besides
entertainment for the onlookers
and participants, is to uncover un-

suspected track talent. For this
reason, the following regular
members of the track team are
barred: Clarke, Hambleton, Dorcus. Aaronson, Booth, Norwood,
Proctor and Heyn. Clarke, Hopkins' famous dash artist, was discovered in one of these meets.
All students at the University
who have ever done any track
work, or who have any "suppressed desires" along that line
are urged to compete for the honor of their class. Uniforms must
be furnished by the participants
but they need bear no kinship to
the regulation ones. Last year the
Seniors led the field with. Freshmen, Sophomores and Juniors finishing in the order named.

shall arrive, and tap them on the

they will walk beside the coaches,
down the driveway and Charles
Street, and finally come to a halt
at the Gray Goose Inn, the traditional inn of all Cane Club luncheons, where the members of the
Club will dine.
Monday night the Club will hold
the accustomed initiation party at
the Arundel Club. The names of
the initiates have not been disclosed.
The tapping ceremony will no doubt
excite much interest and curiosity
in the student body, as it has always done in former years.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 11, 1924

USE THE LIBRARY
To be a college student is a privilege allowed to only a comparatively small number. The privilege of attending a university extends further than merely going to classes and listening to lectures;
it means also the use of the facilities provided by the university. A
large percentage of college students attend small and inadeqtiately
equipped institutions, not endowed with a gymnasium, a stadium, a
student activities building, a library, and others. Hopkins has not
been fortunate in having endowments and large donations given her
and consequently has been deprived of many buildings actually
needed. However, Hopkins has a fully equipped library recognized
as one of the most complete in the South. Our library is so well
known that scholars come from great distances to peruse rare books
in the possession of our university. Some of our undergraduates
realize what a tremendous fund of information, literature, and art is
stored within its walls. Others never make use of the library but
starve to death in the midst of abundance. These students overlook
the fact that we have a library with shelves upon shelves of books—
books that contain the facts and fancies of three thousand years of
civilization—all free.
To be a college student with the rest, to have the use of the campus and buildings, such as the library, devoted to students is unquestionably pleasant in many ways, but the sense of proprietorship
which so much liberty is likely to bring with it, the tendency to discourtesy and lack of consideration, is just as decidedly unpleasant.
A visitor at Hopkins only a short while ago asked someone on the
News-Letter why "SILENCE" signs are placed in the library.
"These requests for quiet seem to be completely ignored," he said,
"and I notice many of your students use your library as a 'social center' to talk over campus gossip." It is unfortunate that the condition is obvious even to a visitor.

rules. The most important ruling
was the restoring of the extra periods, making decisions imperative.
During the past season the rule provided for ten-minute bouts with a

This caused many draws; the wrestlers were drilled in defensive tactics and resorted to these methods,

thrills.

a year.

THE ENGINEERING SHOW
Reports from those in charge of the Engineering Show indicate
that everything is in readiness for the exhibition. The Show, no
doubt, wll turn out to be a great success. It is another method of
advertising Hopkins, informing outsiders that Hopkins is a university, not a hospital, and that all of its students are "not studying
medicine." Furthermore, the Show may prove a means of attracting
to Hopkins many desirable "prep school" men who otherwise might
not realize the worth and extent of our School of Engineering.

ENGINEER LECTURES ON
CABLE PROBLEMS
The design and construction of
the newest types of electric cables
was explained to an audience of
engineering juniors and seniors
last Monday by William A. Del
Mar, chief engineer of the Habirshaw Electric Cable Company,
Yonkers, N. Y. The address given
in the auditorium of the M. E.
Building, was the third of a series
of lectures on "Engineering Practice."
The highest tension today of
the single wire type carries 45,000
volts, he said. Of three conductors, the highest potential is approximately 27,000 volts. These
figures were presented by Mr. Del
Mar to show the need of the utmost care and skill in the manufacture of cables.
Three possible methods of making cables were presented by the
speaker. The simplest method,
he explained, is to insert a single
conductor in a cylinder, with only
the air between them serving as
an insulating medium. However,
he declared, the best material to
do away with surface leakage is
ordinary oil. This, he said, has the
disadvantage of extreme fluidity,
which is overcome by using some
variety of grease, preferably petroleum grease.
Detailed construction of the
present day high tension electric
cable was clearly shown by means
of photographs of the machines in
use in the Habirshaw Electric Cable Company.
Although the construction of an
electric cable may seem rather
simple to the layman, Mr. Del
Mar declared that every branch

Our campus was visited last
Monday by no less a potentate
than the Prince of Egypt, who arrived in all his glory at lunch hour.
The "prince," whose custom it is
to visit Hopkins annually, entered
in state, dragging a large and
somewhat greasy rope after him.
A large crowd soon gathered, and
the dark man from Egypt expressed the wish to be tied up,
promising that with a little financial encouragement from his Spectators, he would outdo Houdini in
loosening his bonds. Several campus dignitaries eagerly set to
work to bind firmly his hands and
arms, while others passed around
the hat, to his Highnesses' unutterable delight. When his captors
had finished tying him, he made
one last dramatic appeal for largesse. and then in a businesslike

manner proceeded to free himself,
amid approving howls and "zitos,"
reminiscent of "The Galloper."
Up to this point, his Highness
had withheld his identity, but enraged by disrespectful remarks
from some irreverent onlooker, he
threatened his disparager with instant decapitation should he ever
venture on his Egyptian domains.
Urged on by his admirers he sang
two of his native folk songs:
"Stop Your Ticklin,' Jock," and "1
Love a Lassie." With more financial aggrandizement in view, he
allowed himself to be trussed up
again, and this time the deed was
done in a very thorough manner.
However, he had just made another successful getaway when
one o'clock sounded and the students were forced to forsake royalty for their prosaic "labs."

Class rivalry will be temporarily
revived this afternoon at 4 o'clock
When the first starting pistol will
be fired in the Annual Inter-class
Track Meet.
An attractive card of events has
been arranged. Any man with any
talent at all on the track will be
able to find a favorable opening.
The races and other competitions
are as follows: 100, 220 and 440Yard dashes, 880-yard, mile and 2mile runs, high and low hurdles,
running high jump, running broad
Jump, javelin and discus throws,
and shotput and pole vault.
The object of the meet, besides
entertainment for the onlookers
and participants, is to uncover un-

suspected track talent. For this
reason, the following regular
members of the track team are
barred: Clarke, Hambleton, Dorcus. Aaronson, Booth, Norwood,
Proctor and Heyn. Clarke, Hopkins' famous dash artist, was discovered in one of these meets.
All students at the University
who have ever done any track
work, or who have any "suppressed desires" along that line
are urged to compete for the honor of their class. Uniforms must
be furnished by the participants
but they need bear no kinship to
the regulation ones. Last year the
Seniors led the field with. Freshmen, Sophomores and Juniors finishing in the order named.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 11, 1924

USE THE LIBRARY
To be a college student is a privilege allowed to only a comparatively small number. The privilege of attending a university extends further than merely going to classes and listening to lectures;
it means also the use of the facilities provided by the university. A
large percentage of college students attend small and inadeqtiately
equipped institutions, not endowed with a gymnasium, a stadium, a
student activities building, a library, and others. Hopkins has not
been fortunate in having endowments and large donations given her
and consequently has been deprived of many buildings actually
needed. However, Hopkins has a fully equipped library recognized
as one of the most complete in the South. Our library is so well
known that scholars come from great distances to peruse rare books
in the possession of our university. Some of our undergraduates
realize what a tremendous fund of information, literature, and art is
stored within its walls. Others never make use of the library but
starve to death in the midst of abundance. These students overlook
the fact that we have a library with shelves upon shelves of books—
books that contain the facts and fancies of three thousand years of
civilization—all free.
To be a college student with the rest, to have the use of the campus and buildings, such as the library, devoted to students is unquestionably pleasant in many ways, but the sense of proprietorship
which so much liberty is likely to bring with it, the tendency to discourtesy and lack of consideration, is just as decidedly unpleasant.
A visitor at Hopkins only a short while ago asked someone on the
News-Letter why "SILENCE" signs are placed in the library.
"These requests for quiet seem to be completely ignored," he said,
"and I notice many of your students use your library as a 'social center' to talk over campus gossip." It is unfortunate that the condition is obvious even to a visitor.

Reports from those in charge of the Engineering Show indicate
that everything is in readiness for the exhibition. The Show, no
doubt, wll turn out to be a great success. It is another method of

to Hopkins many desirable "prep school" men who otherwise might
not realize the worth and extent of our School of Engineering.

ENGINEER LECTURES ON
CABLE PROBLEMS
The design and construction of
the newest types of electric cables
was explained to an audience of
engineering juniors and seniors
last Monday by William A. Del
Mar, chief engineer of the Habirshaw Electric Cable Company,
Yonkers, N. Y. The address given
in the auditorium of the M. E.
Building, was the third of a series
of lectures on "Engineering Practice."
The highest tension today of
the single wire type carries 45,000
volts, he said. Of three conductors, the highest potential is approximately 27,000 volts. These
figures were presented by Mr. Del
Mar to show the need of the utmost care and skill in the manufacture of cables.
Three possible methods of making cables were presented by the
speaker. The simplest method,
he explained, is to insert a single
conductor in a cylinder, with only
the air between them serving as
an insulating medium. However,
he declared, the best material to
do away with surface leakage is
ordinary oil. This, he said, has the
disadvantage of extreme fluidity,
which is overcome by using some
variety of grease, preferably petroleum grease.
Detailed construction of the
present day high tension electric
cable was clearly shown by means
of photographs of the machines in
use in the Habirshaw Electric Cable Company.
Although the construction of an
electric cable may seem rather
simple to the layman, Mr. Del
Mar declared that every branch
of science must be used in order
to handle the problem.

Our campus was visited last
Monday by no less a potentate
than the Prince of Egypt, who arrived in all his glory at lunch hour.
The "prince," whose custom it is
to visit Hopkins annually, entered
in state, dragging a large and
somewhat greasy rope after him.
A large crowd soon gathered, and
the dark man from Egypt expressed the wish to be tied up,
promising that with a little financial encouragement from his Spectators, he would outdo Houdini in
loosening his bonds. Several campus dignitaries eagerly set to
work to bind firmly his hands and
arms, while others passed around
the hat, to his Highnesses' unutterable delight. When his captors
had finished tying him, he made
one last dramatic appeal for largesse. and then in a businesslike

manner proceeded to free himself,
amid approving howls and "zitos,"
reminiscent of "The Galloper."
Up to this point, his Highness
had withheld his identity, but enraged by disrespectful remarks
from some irreverent onlooker, he
threatened his disparager with instant decapitation should he ever
venture on his Egyptian domains.
Urged on by his admirers he sang
two of his native folk songs:
"Stop Your Ticklin,' Jock," and "1
Love a Lassie." With more financial aggrandizement in view, he
allowed himself to be trussed up
again, and this time the deed was
done in a very thorough manner.
However, he had just made another successful getaway when
one o'clock sounded and the students were forced to forsake royalty for their prosaic "labs."
